body:
Ramblings of a Jonsa fan

I think by the end of this next season people will be having a change of heart about our girl Sansa.

I feel her character is often treated like Betty Draper’s (another misunderstood character) and suddenly people were sad with her end storyline.

Her character arc has been amazing and underappreciated for too long.

I will admit that in the beginning I thought Dany and Jon were endgame but as the seasons progressed I felt Dany’s storyline was going in the opposite moral direction of Jon’s. Then season six happened and suddenly I started seeing Jon and Sansa as a pair and potential endgame. Their scenes together were just magnetic but I thought maybe I had read Flowers in the Attic too much. Then I came on here and found like minded people but still thought it was a long shot.

Season seven happened and when we found out Jon would be meeting Dany I resigned myself to the idea that this would be the epic love story. However it fell flat. It was obvious they had different objectives and priorities and paths to achieve those goals. They had no chemistry. My sister was a jonerys fan and even she said the pairing felt dull and anti climatic. She’s now team Jonsa.

Yes they had sex but people are out there acting like sex always equates love and no matter how you slice it having Bran narrating as it’s happening and showing scenes from another problematic pairing (Rhaegar and lyanna) does not forebode well for them.

Either way I love this fandom and all you amazing people with your incredible insight. It definitely makes me feel less alone with my opinions on the show and that I wasn’t just the girl who may have read VC Andrews too much.

That’s all my ramblings for today.

body:
Ok…this is the italian trailer on sky and this are my thought:

1. Sansa cames first and looks up to the dragons. After that we have the crypt’s scene with D*ny and Jon. It’s again a triangle formation like they want you to pay attention to the three of them.

2. The light is much better then the english trailer and I’m relieved cause I thought we couldn’t see anything when the time comes for that episode.

3. It’s just me or Jamie said Tyron? Please if someone can answer me cause I didn’t really understand.

4. I don’t know if that’s just me but it’s like they’re pairing the characters. First shot Sansa followed by Jon and D*ny. Then Gendry followed by Arya. Then Missandei and Grey Worm. Or Jamie followed by Tyron and after that Drogon…I don’t know what I’m trying to say but I see a pattern?!

What do you think?

summary: [In which Petyr and Sansa have a morning’s distraction from their plans of revenge] “We could wait an hour, stay in bed until...
caption:
[In which Petyr and Sansa have a morning’s distraction from their plans of revenge]

“We could wait an hour, stay in bed until then,” she says, yawning and stretching her arms so that the covers slide down and bare her tits as he breathes a laugh.

“It’s tempting, very tempting,” he says, leaning forward so the silken sides of his jacket touch her bare skin, so that he can press a dry kiss to her nipple that makes her quiver, before he pulls back, holds himself above her by his hands. “But we’re late, we can’t.”

“Then I’m not coming,” she says grumpily.

- a morning’s distraction

trail.content:
[In which Petyr and Sansa have a morning’s distraction from their plans of revenge]

“We could wait an hour, stay in bed until then,” she says, yawning and stretching her arms so that the covers slide down and bare her tits as he breathes a laugh.

“It’s tempting, very tempting,” he says, leaning forward so the silken sides of his jacket touch her bare skin, so that he can press a dry kiss to her nipple that makes her quiver, before he pulls back, holds himself above her by his hands. “But we’re late, we can’t.”

“Then I’m not coming,” she says grumpily.

- a morning’s distraction

title: Re: “Kidnap Plot”
body:
I just read a post by the “other side” questioning why the “kidnap plot” is so popular with Jonsas and why we would want our fave to go through this and how this would not do her character any favours (i.e. it puts her back into the damsel-in-distress role) and while I would not want to jump on their post, I think it’s valid point and fair to discuss this. 

1. The “kidnap plot” is not half as popular with Jonsas (and especially not Sansa-only stans) in this fandom as the poster makes it out to be. In fact, a lot of people dread seeing Sansa in any form of “danger” again or, as the JD person argued, as a “damsel in distress” .

And I would say that - kidnap or no kidnap - Sansa *is* bound to be in shitloads of danger in Season 8 simply by being alive. Winterfell is going to be a major battle field and she has powerful opponents and enemies simply for who she is and in her position. Unless she dies right away in the WW attack, there is bound to be a scenario in which Sansa is put in a position where her agency and perceived “safety” is taken away again - at least temporarily. She is a major character and what is more: she is important to a lot of other characters, that’s why I think a “kidnap” is very likely…

2. Why is every scenario where a female character is in danger and saved by another character automatically considered to be the much frowned upon “damsel” trope? Brienne-in-the-bear-pit could hold her own against a bear for a minute, but also needed to be “saved” by the male character Jaime, yet we do not think of her as weak or stupid or a cliché. Brienne is a great fighter, yet she needed to be “saved” in the end. What is more: the fact that Jaime saved her only pertained to the romantic-ness of the trope. 

3. And while it is a romance trope and could very well support our ship (i.e. if it is Jon who comes to Sansa’s rescue) that is not the main point why I think the “kidnap plot” makes sense and is important: it is about Cersei and Sansa, aka the YMBQ. 

The kidnap plot that is supposedly so reactionary and bad for Sansa’s character development is imo going to be her big break. Because Sansa was hiding in Winterfell. It is her home and it is her safe zone, but it is not her destiny to hide from her enemies forever.  

The same way that Cersei has unfinished business with Sansa, Sansa also has unfinished business with Cersei, she just hasn’t realized it yet. 

I know that D and JD stans like to imagine that *everything* is about their queen and their ship, but fact is that the relationship between the Starks and the Lannisters has zero to do with Dani or Jon*erys. It is one of the central conflicts and needs resolution. Arya is the one who wants to kill Cersei for what she did to the Stark. However, Cersei does not want to kill Arya, what she wants is Sansa. 

The reason why some Jonsa and Sansa stans like me do not see the “kidnap plot” as throwing Sansa back into her role from earlier seasons is that while the scenario has not changed and Cersei has not changed, one thing has changed big time:

Sansa. 

Of course haters and antis imagine that Sansa would be nothing more than a weak, crying damsel again, because that is ALL they will ever see in her. They refuse to acknowledge that even outside of Winterfell’s safe space, Sansa has changed and will be a strong, clever, calculating force to be reckoned with. 

IF Cersei has Sansa “fetched” and brought back to her, she will have brought her own doom back under her roof. 

My final point is: the “kidnap plot” (IF it even happens) and an empowerment of Sansa do not have to be mutually exclusive plot points. If you believe that Sansa will let Cersei walk all over her again, then you have probably not paid a lot of attention to her in the past three to four seasons.

Sansa can be both a strong female character who can hold her own against another strong female character and yet be rescued out of her clutches by a male hero without losing her integrity or looking weak. 

Everyone is always focused on the possible “rescue” from a possible “kidnap” but what about what happens in between? What about the awesome possibility of seeing Sansa play Cersei like a fiddle, of Sansa outwitting Cersei who forced her to “come” to King’s Landing again to “cast her down.”

I’m here for it, kidnap or no kidnap.

blog.name: fortunatelylori
blog.title: Thoughts on the verge
blog.description:
Pretty much Game of Throne and Jonsa all day, every day. 
Avatar and header by @ragekitn

summary: Unpopular opinion: I think Sansa is manipulating Jon. Not in every interaction and not to hurt him. But manipulation is a skill...
question: Unpopular opinion: I think Sansa is manipulating Jon. Not in every interaction and not to hurt him. But manipulation is a skill she's learned and we've seen her use it against other characters from the beginning e.g. joffrey, baelish, Lords of vale. I think we see this with Jon when she tells him they need to save Rickon knowing they had no chance, when she touches him to get him to listen, especially after the first time, and even when she uses that patronizing tone to compare him to joffrey.
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

You are certainly entitled to your opinion and I encourage all Jonsa and Sansa fans to express their views, independent of how popular they are. I think discourse and debate are very healthy. 

However, I would have to disagree with your interpretation. I can understand what might give you that impression and, in my opinion, it all has to do with the hidden POV technique that the writers employ for Sansa over and over again. It’s one of the main reasons why I hate this narrative choice so much. It leaves far too much room for interpretation in regards to her actions, motivations and decisions and that causes people to disconnect from her. 

The main reason why I don’t believe that Sansa is manipulating Jon is that if she is indeed trying to manipulate him, she’s doing a thoroughly terrible job of it. Jon almost never does anything Sansa advises or wants him to do, he disregards her advice time and time again and cuts her out of important decisions. So either Sansa isn’t trying to manipulate him or she’s just a crappy manipulator all together. Considering that, as you say, Sansa has been forced to use manipulation in the past in order to survive, I just can’t believe that she’d be so bad at it with Jon.

I also don’t really see what her end goal for this manipulation might be? 

She wants power? If she wanted that, she wouldn’t have spent the whole of season 7 fighting to keep Jon’s armies intact and she wouldn’t have executed Littlefinger. LF wanted to usurp Jon’s throne and put Sansa in his place. Sansa responded to that by holding a public trial for him. 

She doesn’t trust him? I’ll be the first to say that Sansa has trust issues but that’s not limited to Jon. She doesn’t fully trust anyone because of everything that has happened to her. I think that, as far as she can trust anyone, she trusts Jon. If she didn’t, she wouldn’t have continued to support him after he sent her a scroll announcing he bent the knee with no explanation. 

She just wants to get her way? Again, she almost never does get her way. 

Just to briefly touch on the examples you gave: 

I think we see this with Jon when she tells him they need to save Rickon knowing they had no chance

See? This is a prime example of why cutting us off from Sansa’s POV works against her character. But I do think this is a misinterpretation of Sansa’s state of mind at the time. 

I don’t think that during the scene where she convinces Jon to go to war with Ramsay, Sansa believes Rickon is as good as dead. She knows there’s a possibility that Ramsay will kill him but I believe she also hopes that they can in fact save him. 

Here’s the thing: Sansa is not a callous person. She loves her family. I don’t think it’s easy for her to admit that Rickon will die. She wants to believe he can be saved, hence the sense of urgency when she grabs Jon’s hand to plead with him to go to war. 

If she had truly wanted to manipulate Jon in that scene, she would have really emphasized her own abuse at Ramsay’s hands. She never does. All she does is plead with Jon to fight for something he clearly already wants to fight for but doesn’t believe he can. She empowers him. 

It’s also a similar action to what Jon does with D*ny in the cave scene in season 7. Jon isn’t manipulating D*ny . He’s asking for help, trying to explain the situation to her as best he can and trying to drive home the importance of “working together”. He acts very differently from the Jon on the boat after the wight hunt, when he is very obviously manipulating her by using any means he has at his disposal.

One more thing that really signals to me that Sansa thinks Rickon can be saved in that scene is the way she reacts to Ramsay during the parlay. She is stoic and stands her ground when Ramsay addresses her directly, she makes it a point to be there but as soon as Ramsay throws Shaggy Dog’s head on the ground and begins to talk about Rickon, you can see Sansa’s whole demeanor change. I think this is the moment she realizes Ramsay will kill Rickon and they have absolutely no chance of getting him back. Hence her saying: 

Sansa: You’re going to die tomorrow, Lord Bolton. Sleep well. 

That’s fuled by Rickon as is her abrupt departure from a parlay she insisted she wanted to participate in. It’s very likely to me that she rides off at that time because she’s about to break down in tears and she doesn’t want to give Ramsay the satisfaction. Just speculation, of course, because, again, the writers aren’t interested in giving me 1 on 1 access to Sansa because, and I can’t stress this enough, THEY’RE EVIL! (not really; just in love with stupid, unearned story twists … hello, Winterhell plot!)

when she touches him to get him to listen

I’m a Jonsa so I think it’s far more likely she touches him because she wants to touch him. And very importantly, she feels comfortable enough around him to touch him. Also, particularly in season 7, Jon seems to actively try to run away from her, if not physically, at least emotionally. Sansa seems to sense this subconsciously, hence her pulling on his arm to draw him back. She pleads with him over and over again to include her more, to listen to her and to talk to her. That doesn’t feel like manipulation to me. Frustration, certainly and also a desire to be important in his life and be taken into account. She’s very clear about that. 

even when she uses that patronizing tone to compare him to Joffrey

I’m not sure comparing Jon to the worst person she knows is really an effective manipulation strategy. In fact it does the opposite: it offends Jon and she has to backtrack out of it as quickly as possible. 

I’ve talked about this in the past and I’ve said that the Joffrey comparison is a manipulation but not by Sansa against Jon but rather by the writers against the audience because they are actively trying to push the Dark Sansa red herring in season 7 in preparation for the Winterhell plot. 

Within the story, I’d say that this comparison is fuled by Sansa’s frustration as well as her traumas. She connects Jon to Joffrey because there’s a part of her that is always scared of ending up in the same situation she was in. She keeps telling herself she can’t trust anyone and keeps reminding herself of the Joffreys and the Ramsays that have hurt and used her in order to keep her guard up. 

This has very little to do with wanting to manipulate Jon and everything to do with her trauma. Which is why she looks so guilty when Jon calls her out on it. I don’t think she even realizes what she’s saying until she sees just how hurt Jon is by it. 

Thanks for the ask!

Within the story, I’d say that this comparison is fuled by Sansa’s frustration as well as her traumas. She connects Jon to Joffrey because there’s a part of her that is always scared of ending up in the same situation she was in. She keeps telling herself she can’t trust anyone and keeps reminding herself of the Joffreys and the Ramsays that have hurt and used her in order to keep her guard up. 

This has very little to do with wanting to manipulate Jon and everything to do with her trauma. Which is why she looks so guilty when Jon calls her out on it. I don’t think she even realizes what she’s saying until she sees just how hurt Jon is by it. 

Thanks for the ask!

trail.content_raw:
Hey, nonnie!

You are certainly entitled to your opinion and I encourage all Jonsa and Sansa fans to express their views, independent of how popular they are. I think discourse and debate are very healthy. 

However, I would have to disagree with your interpretation. I can understand what might give you that impression and, in my opinion, it all has to do with the hidden POV technique that the writers employ for Sansa over and over again. It’s one of the main reasons why I hate this narrative choice so much. It leaves far too much room for interpretation in regards to her actions, motivations and decisions and that causes people to disconnect from her. 

The main reason why I don’t believe that Sansa is manipulating Jon is that if she is indeed trying to manipulate him, she’s doing a thoroughly terrible job of it. Jon almost never does anything Sansa advises or wants him to do, he disregards her advice time and time again and cuts her out of important decisions. So either Sansa isn’t trying to manipulate him or she’s just a crappy manipulator all together. Considering that, as you say, Sansa has been forced to use manipulation in the past in order to survive, I just can’t believe that she’d be so bad at it with Jon.

I also don’t really see what her end goal for this manipulation might be? 

She wants power? If she wanted that, she wouldn’t have spent the whole of season 7 fighting to keep Jon’s armies intact and she wouldn’t have executed Littlefinger. LF wanted to usurp Jon’s throne and put Sansa in his place. Sansa responded to that by holding a public trial for him. 

She doesn’t trust him? I’ll be the first to say that Sansa has trust issues but that’s not limited to Jon. She doesn’t fully trust anyone because of everything that has happened to her. I think that, as far as she can trust anyone, she trusts Jon. If she didn’t, she wouldn’t have continued to support him after he sent her a scroll announcing he bent the knee with no explanation. 

She just wants to get her way? Again, she almost never does get her way. 

Just to briefly touch on the examples you gave: 

I think we see this with Jon when she tells him they need to save Rickon knowing they had no chance

See? This is a prime example of why cutting us off from Sansa’s POV works against her character. But I do think this is a misinterpretation of Sansa’s state of mind at the time. 

I don’t think that during the scene where she convinces Jon to go to war with Ramsay, Sansa believes Rickon is as good as dead. She knows there’s a possibility that Ramsay will kill him but I believe she also hopes that they can in fact save him. 

Here’s the thing: Sansa is not a callous person. She loves her family. I don’t think it’s easy for her to admit that Rickon will die. She wants to believe he can be saved, hence the sense of urgency when she grabs Jon’s hand to plead with him to go to war. 

If she had truly wanted to manipulate Jon in that scene, she would have really emphasized her own abuse at Ramsay’s hands. She never does. All she does is plead with Jon to fight for something he clearly already wants to fight for but doesn’t believe he can. She empowers him. 

It’s also a similar action to what Jon does with D*ny in the cave scene in season 7. Jon isn’t manipulating D*ny . He’s asking for help, trying to explain the situation to her as best he can and trying to drive home the importance of “working together”. He acts very differently from the Jon on the boat after the wight hunt, when he is very obviously manipulating her by using any means he has at his disposal.

One more thing that really signals to me that Sansa thinks Rickon can be saved in that scene is the way she reacts to Ramsay during the parlay. She is stoic and stands her ground when Ramsay addresses her directly, she makes it a point to be there but as soon as Ramsay throws Shaggy Dog’s head on the ground and begins to talk about Rickon, you can see Sansa’s whole demeanor change. I think this is the moment she realizes Ramsay will kill Rickon and they have absolutely no chance of getting him back. Hence her saying: 

Sansa: You’re going to die tomorrow, Lord Bolton. Sleep well. 

That’s fuled by Rickon as is her abrupt departure from a parlay she insisted she wanted to participate in. It’s very likely to me that she rides off at that time because she’s about to break down in tears and she doesn’t want to give Ramsay the satisfaction. Just speculation, of course, because, again, the writers aren’t interested in giving me 1 on 1 access to Sansa because, and I can’t stress this enough, THEY’RE EVIL! (not really; just in love with stupid, unearned story twists … hello, Winterhell plot!)

when she touches him to get him to listen

I’m a Jonsa so I think it’s far more likely she touches him because she wants to touch him. And very importantly, she feels comfortable enough around him to touch him. Also, particularly in season 7, Jon seems to actively try to run away from her, if not physically, at least emotionally. Sansa seems to sense this subconsciously, hence her pulling on his arm to draw him back. She pleads with him over and over again to include her more, to listen to her and to talk to her. That doesn’t feel like manipulation to me. Frustration, certainly and also a desire to be important in his life and be taken into account. She’s very clear about that. 

even when she uses that patronizing tone to compare him to Joffrey

I’m not sure comparing Jon to the worst person she knows is really an effective manipulation strategy. In fact it does the opposite: it offends Jon and she has to backtrack out of it as quickly as possible. 

I’ve talked about this in the past and I’ve said that the Joffrey comparison is a manipulation but not by Sansa against Jon but rather by the writers against the audience because they are actively trying to push the Dark Sansa red herring in season 7 in preparation for the Winterhell plot. 

Within the story, I’d say that this comparison is fuled by Sansa’s frustration as well as her traumas. She connects Jon to Joffrey because there’s a part of her that is always scared of ending up in the same situation she was in. She keeps telling herself she can’t trust anyone and keeps reminding herself of the Joffreys and the Ramsays that have hurt and used her in order to keep her guard up. 

This has very little to do with wanting to manipulate Jon and everything to do with her trauma. Which is why she looks so guilty when Jon calls her out on it. I don’t think she even realizes what she’s saying until she sees just how hurt Jon is by it. 

Thanks for the ask!

title: “Especially Now”, Jon x Sansa fanfiction
body:
Eh, so I went to the dentist a few days ago to have my wisdom tooth pulled. Despite being on a shitload of anaesthetics/painkillers, I needed a distraction from all the pain, hence - this. (And also I may have found out where the name “wisdom tooth” comes from. Since the extraction I’ve been feeling considerably dumber than usual, I believe that tooth may have contained a huge chunk of my usual eloquence, now irrevocably gone.)

If you prefer reading on ao3, here’s a link.


Title: “Especially Now”

Relationship: Jon/Sansa

Wordcount: 1742

Tags: love confessions (sort of), godswood, post-parentage reveal, mild hurt/comfort, POV Sansa, Post-season 7, before battle



ESPECIALLY NOW


It’s been three days since they learned the truth, and Jon doesn’t seem to be getting better. The Others are closer every day, Bran says, but Jon is either staring at the walls during meetings or he’s disappearing for hours, maybe longer. Even Daenerys Targaryen grows suspicious.

„Lady Sansa, forgive me,” she interrupts her once, smiling kindly. Littlefinger was right, she is the most stunning woman Sansa has ever laid eyes on. The worry suits her, too. Her face becomes softer, almost girly, a shadow of who they all were before the world forced them to grow up. „There are some final arrangements that we need to consult with your brother, but he is nowhere to be found. Would you please ask him to visit Lord Tyrion’s chambers as soon as you see him?”

It’s not even an order, it’s a plea. The Dragon Queen is concerned—and so is Sansa.

She gives Daenerys a brief nod and gets back to her solar to put on her coat. There is only one place where he would seek solace other than the crypts—and he’s definitely not in the crypts, Arya’s already checked.

It’s not possible to sneak up on somebody in the godswood, the snow crunching under Sansa’s feet announces her presence long before she reaches a hunched, miserable creature sitting on one of the roots. He knows that he’s no longer alone, she takes it from the way his shoulders tense up under a leather jerkin.

“If you want to freeze yourself to death, could you please do it after the Night King is defeated?” Sansa asks, and it’s supposed to sound playful but comes out almost mean. She bites her lip, comes a few steps closer, and then covers him with another fur, the one she’s been carrying through Winterfell’s courtyards, raising curious glances.

She lingers a while longer with her hand on Jon’s shoulder. “I’m with you,” she wants to say, but somehow the reassurance refuses to form. They’ve been telling him the same thing for days, why would he decide to listen to her now? He needs to be alone, she knows that, but unfortunately, it’s the last thing they should let him do. They are his family and nothing will change it.

Jon doesn’t move for another two or three minutes, and Sansa begins to consider releasing his shoulder and retreating to the safety of her solar when suddenly he raises his hand and places it over Sansa’s. She’s got her gloves on, but even through thick leather she can feel the icy touch. She glances down and realises that his hand went almost blue from the cold.

“Jon!” she yells at him—or maybe just whispers, it’s all very quiet around here, she wouldn’t want to disturb the gods—and crunches down in front of Jon to force him to look at her. “You need to snap out of this,” she says, a tinge of rebuke in her voice. “We need you. Not in some fight against the dead that we may as well lose even with you leading our armies. We need you as our family. Arya and Bran need you. I need you.”

Jon finally looks at her—and there’s so much pain in his eyes, it almost physically hurts Sansa to see him like that. She takes both of his hands in hers—partly to make him listen to what she has to say more carefully, the touch always seems to work magic between them, and partly to warm them up—and tugs them under her furs, close to her heart.

“I’m sorry that it happened, Jon. I truly am. No one should have to find out such things after years of carefully building their identity around some scraps that turned out to be lies. You might think that I have no idea of what I speak, but I too was always proven to be wrong about everything I wanted to be. It’s offensive to compare these two, I know, but please take it from the deepest, most honest part of my soul: you might not be our brother, but you will always be our family. There’s only four of us left, you and I, and Arya, and Bran. We are the pack. We are a family. We are the Starks.”

“I’m not a Stark,” he says grimly with a hoarse voice. Sansa is certain he’s been crying for the better part of the last few days. She’d do anything to make him understand.

“You are,” she insists. “Don’t be ridiculous. As far as I’m concerned this only proves you are more of a Stark than you’ve been thus far.” Jon doesn’t look away for a second, as if searching for something in her eyes that would make him believe her words. He seems so lost, she just wants to lock him in a tight embrace and never let go. “I know my mother was never kind to you. Your identity was a hurtful lie she died believing, and it breaks my heart to imagine how different our lives might have been in different circumstances. I hope you forgive her, and I hope she forgives Father for what he put her through. But Father… He loved you with all his heart. If you think even for a minute that Ned Stark wasn’t your true parent—” Jon squeezes her hand tight as if he’s clinging to this declaration. “I don’t care whose blood you share. Father risked everything he held dear to give you a good life, to protect you from King Robert’s wrath, from all the enemies who might have come for your head, had they learned the truth. He raised you as his own, and I’m sure he died regretting that the truth was dying with him. You are a Stark on your father’s side, and now you’re a Stark on your mother’s side, too. In fact, you’re more of a Stark than any of us. Arya, Bran, and I are all half-Stark and half-Tully,” she smiles.

And Jon looks at her for a moment with bright eyes—Sansa thinks there might be tears forming in them but it’s something else entirely, something thrilling, challenging even. And then he smiles back. It’s weak and lasts only a mere second, but it’s undeniably there. Jon pulls her closer and buries his face in her furs.

“You don’t have to be kind to me,” he murmurs.

Sansa rolls her eyes.

“Of course I don’t have to be kind to you, you dummy. I choose to be kind to you because I love you,” she says angrily, and to make her point stronger places a soft kiss to the top of his head, not unlike the one he once gifted to her.

They stay like that for a while, hugging tightly, their arms tangled together, Jon breathing into Sansa’s neck and Sansa stroking the top of his head with her nose, until it dawns on them how strange they must look from the outside.

Well, it certainly dawns on Sansa, because when she suddenly pulls back, Jon seems to have been taken by surprise.

“I’m sorry,” he says with a mortified expression, “was I making you uncomfortable?”

“Uncomfortable?” She blinks at him. “Of course not. Why would you make me uncomfortable?”

There’s a long, silent moment when Jon studies her face carefully as if it is the first time he ever sees her. Then he lets go of her hands and hides his own under his cloak.

“If I asked you a question… Would you answer truthfully?”

It should probably offend her that he would think otherwise, but she decides not to comment on that. He’s way too vulnerable to deal with her wounded pride just yet.

Instead, Sansa simply nods.

It seems to be as good an encouragement as any, because Jon makes this stupid face which he uses when he’s being stubborn: like when he insisted on going to a fight with just a bunch of men, or when he declared that he would be riding south to convince Daenerys Targaryen to fight for them. Only this time it’s about something much more personal, she can feel it.

Jon lowers his eyes almost as if he can’t look at Sansa while he asks.

“About what you said earlier.”

Sansa expects him to continue, but that’s all she seems to be getting.

“I said many things, Jon,” she sighs.

“You said you loved me.” Ah, that. “Why?”

His voice is shaking, he sounds almost too afraid to be hopeful. It breaks her heart.

“What do you mean why? I said it because it is how I feel. You are the most important person in the entire world to me.”

Although Sansa has never wondered about it before, she knows in her heart that it’s true. She loves Arya and Bran more than she loves herself, but Jon is the first person she ever loved for who he was and what they shared together, not someone whom she was conditioned to love no matter what. Maybe it was lady Catelyn’s doing. Maybe it was for the better.

Jon still refuses to look her in the eye.

“Even now?” he asks quietly. “Even after it’s been revealed that I’m not your brother?”

“Especially now,” she answers without really giving it much thought. Seeing that he finally raises his head and stares at her, she gives him an encouraging smile and stands up. Turning to get back to the castle, she hears him whisper:

“Sansa.”

Something about the tone of his voice stops her in her tracks. She doesn’t turn back to him, hit by freezing wind from the North. For a short moment Sansa fears that they’re nearing the end at last, that Winterfell might be under attack, but then she hears Jon’s pleading words:

“Especially now?” There’s a thunder coming from afar. Or maybe it’s just the beating of Sansa’s heart? “Why especially?”

And at this moment, witnessed by the old gods, Sansa finally realises.

She loves Jon, yes.

But she’s also in love with Jon.

A terrifying awakening, and one that is followed by the sound of horns from the gates. “They’re here,” Sansa thinks, and Jon looks at her for the last time before he grabs her hand and they run together towards the castle. “Please,” she prays to the gods, “please let us live, so that I may tell him one day.”

And Jon looks at her for a moment with bright eyes—Sansa thinks there might be tears forming in them but it’s something else entirely, something thrilling, challenging even. And then he smiles back. It’s weak and lasts only a mere second, but it’s undeniably there. Jon pulls her closer and buries his face in her furs.

“You don’t have to be kind to me,” he murmurs.

Sansa rolls her eyes.

“Of course I don’t have to be kind to you, you dummy. I choose to be kind to you because I love you,” she says angrily, and to make her point stronger places a soft kiss to the top of his head, not unlike the one he once gifted to her.

They stay like that for a while, hugging tightly, their arms tangled together, Jon breathing into Sansa’s neck and Sansa stroking the top of his head with her nose, until it dawns on them how strange they must look from the outside.

Well, it certainly dawns on Sansa, because when she suddenly pulls back, Jon seems to have been taken by surprise.

“I’m sorry,” he says with a mortified expression, “was I making you uncomfortable?”

“Uncomfortable?” She blinks at him. “Of course not. Why would you make me uncomfortable?”

There’s a long, silent moment when Jon studies her face carefully as if it is the first time he ever sees her. Then he lets go of her hands and hides his own under his cloak.

“If I asked you a question… Would you answer truthfully?”

It should probably offend her that he would think otherwise, but she decides not to comment on that. He’s way too vulnerable to deal with her wounded pride just yet.

Instead, Sansa simply nods.

It seems to be as good an encouragement as any, because Jon makes this stupid face which he uses when he’s being stubborn: like when he insisted on going to a fight with just a bunch of men, or when he declared that he would be riding south to convince Daenerys Targaryen to fight for them. Only this time it’s about something much more personal, she can feel it.

Jon lowers his eyes almost as if he can’t look at Sansa while he asks.

“About what you said earlier.”

Sansa expects him to continue, but that’s all she seems to be getting.

“I said many things, Jon,” she sighs.

“You said you loved me.” Ah, that. “Why?”

His voice is shaking, he sounds almost too afraid to be hopeful. It breaks her heart.

“What do you mean why? I said it because it is how I feel. You are the most important person in the entire world to me.”

Although Sansa has never wondered about it before, she knows in her heart that it’s true. She loves Arya and Bran more than she loves herself, but Jon is the first person she ever loved for who he was and what they shared together, not someone whom she was conditioned to love no matter what. Maybe it was lady Catelyn’s doing. Maybe it was for the better.

Jon still refuses to look her in the eye.

“Even now?” he asks quietly. “Even after it’s been revealed that I’m not your brother?”

“Especially now,” she answers without really giving it much thought. Seeing that he finally raises his head and stares at her, she gives him an encouraging smile and stands up. Turning to get back to the castle, she hears him whisper:

“Sansa.”

Something about the tone of his voice stops her in her tracks. She doesn’t turn back to him, hit by freezing wind from the North. For a short moment Sansa fears that they’re nearing the end at last, that Winterfell might be under attack, but then she hears Jon’s pleading words:

“Especially now?” There’s a thunder coming from afar. Or maybe it’s just the beating of Sansa’s heart? “Why especially?”

And at this moment, witnessed by the old gods, Sansa finally realises.

She loves Jon, yes.

But she’s also in love with Jon.

A terrifying awakening, and one that is followed by the sound of horns from the gates. “They’re here,” Sansa thinks, and Jon looks at her for the last time before he grabs her hand and they run together towards the castle. “Please,” she prays to the gods, “please let us live, so that I may tell him one day.”

Eh, so I went to the dentist a few days ago to have my wisdom tooth pulled. Despite being on a shitload of anaesthetics/painkillers, I needed a distraction from all the pain, hence - this. Title: “Especially Now”

Relationship: Jon/Sansa

Tags: love confessions (sort of), godswood, post-parentage reveal, mild hurt/comfort, POV Sansa, Post-season 7, before battle



ESPECIALLY NOW


It’s been three days since they learned the truth, and Jon doesn’t seem to be getting better. The Others are closer every day, Bran says, but Jon is either staring at the walls during meetings or he’s disappearing for hours, maybe longer. Even Daenerys Targaryen grows suspicious.

[[MORE]]

„Lady Sansa, forgive me,” she interrupts her once, smiling kindly. Littlefinger was right, she is the most stunning woman Sansa has ever laid eyes on. The worry suits her, too. Her face becomes softer, almost girly, a shadow of who they all were before the world forced them to grow up. „There are some final arrangements that we need to consult with your brother, but he is nowhere to be found. Would you please ask him to visit Lord Tyrion’s chambers as soon as you see him?”

It’s not even an order, it’s a plea. The Dragon Queen is concerned—and so is Sansa.

She gives Daenerys a brief nod and gets back to her solar to put on her coat. There is only one place where he would seek solace other than the crypts—and he’s definitely not in the crypts, Arya’s already checked.

It’s not possible to sneak up on somebody in the godswood, the snow crunching under Sansa’s feet announces her presence long before she reaches a hunched, miserable creature sitting on one of the roots. He knows that he’s no longer alone, she takes it from the way his shoulders tense up under a leather jerkin.

She bites her lip, comes a few steps closer, and then covers him with another fur, the one she’s been carrying through Winterfell’s courtyards, raising curious glances.

She lingers a while longer with her hand on Jon’s shoulder. “I’m with you,” she wants to say, but somehow the reassurance refuses to form. They’ve been telling him the same thing for days, why would he decide to listen to her now? He needs to be alone, she knows that, but unfortunately, it’s the last thing they should let him do. They are his family and nothing will change it.

Jon doesn’t move for another two or three minutes, and Sansa begins to consider releasing his shoulder and retreating to the safety of her solar when suddenly he raises his hand and places it over Sansa’s. She’s got her gloves on, but even through thick leather she can feel the icy touch. She glances down and realises that his hand went almost blue from the cold.

“Jon!” she yells at him—or maybe just whispers, it’s all very quiet around here, she wouldn’t want to disturb the gods—and crunches down in front of Jon to force him to look at her. “You need to snap out of this,” she says, a tinge of rebuke in her voice. “We need you. She takes both of his hands in hers—partly to make him listen to what she has to say more carefully, the touch always seems to work magic between them, and partly to warm them up—and tugs them under her furs, close to her heart.

“I’m sorry that it happened, Jon. I truly am. No one should have to find out such things after years of carefully building their identity around some scraps that turned out to be lies. “You are,” she insists. “Don’t be ridiculous. body:
“I’m Going To Break the Wheel”

Daenerys in the show is the only person who has vocalized ANY objection to the feudalism that chokes Westeros from any kind of meaningful growth and crushes the smallfolk like bugs.

Even the uwu Starks are fighting for their home, so they can regain their base of power. Northern Independence is giving the Starks more feudal power, not less.

That’s why Daenerys will win in the show. And that’s why she will give up her power, like she did in Meereen, and give it to her people.

That line is there FOR A REASON. That she is the only, ONLY person in the show to vocalize these thoughts, makes her a radical and the only one who should win.

And she will.
